Logs showing changes to domain trust obj.Action: Monitor Windows Event IDs indicating trust modifications (e.g., 4703). Identify the user account performing the change. Analyze the frequency and timing of trust modifications; use time series analysis or simple count anomalies to identify unusual activity spikes.

Security logs indicating modification of.Data: Windows Event ID 307, Windows Event ID 510
Security logs indicating modification of.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 307 and 510 on AD FS servers and Domain Controllers for changes to federation settings. Correlate these events by Instance ID. Investigate any changes setting domain authentication from Managed to Federated or modifying existing federation configurations. Analyze user accounts initiating these changes for legitimacy using baselines.

Audit logs showing the addition of a new.Data: Windows Event ID 307, Windows Event ID 510
Audit logs showing the addition of a new.Action: Monitor Windows Event ID 307 and 510 (if applicable for ADFS configuration changes) or forwarded audit logs for the addition of new identity providers. Analyze the source and context of these events. Use correlation analysis to link these events with other suspicious activities.

Detection of specific PowerShell command.Action: Collect Windows Event ID 4688 (Process Creation) and PowerShell logs. Search for execution of commands like 'Update-MSOLFederatedDomain'. Analyze the command parameters, user account, and host from which the command was executed. Use frequency analysis to identify rare or unauthorized usage of these commands.
